Jaron_Lowenstein:
{{short description|American singer|bot=PearBOT 5}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Jaron Lowenstein | image = | caption = | birth_name = Jaron David Lowenstein | alias = Jaron and the Long Road to Love | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|03|18}}{{cite web | url = http://www.boston.com/news/history/articles/2011/03/18/today_in_history/ | title = Today in History | work = [[The Associated Press]] | date = March 18, 2011 | quote = Evan and Jaron Lowenstein are 37}} | origin = [[Tucker, Georgia|Tucker]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], U.S. | genre = [[Country pop]] | years_active = 1994–present | label = Jaronwood
[[Universal Republic Records]]
[[Big Machine Records|Big Machine]]

Nine North | past_member_of= [[Evan and Jaron]] }} '''Jaron David Lowenstein''' (born March 18, 1974) is an American singer who formerly recorded with his [[identical twin]] brother, Evan, in the musical duo [[Evan and Jaron]]. As '''Jaron and the Long Road to Love''', he released his debut [[single (music)|single]], "Pray for You" to country radio in November 2009. This song reached the top 15 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, and is included on the album ''[[Getting Dressed in the Dark]]''. The second single, "That's Beautiful to Me", was released in September 2010. == Life and career == Lowenstein was born in [[Tucker, Georgia]], the son of Leslie (née Diamond) and Charles Lowenstein. He was raised in an [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] family, and attended [[Greenfield Hebrew Academy]] and [[Yeshiva Atlanta|Yeshiva High School]] (which have since merged to form the [[Atlanta Jewish Academy]]){{cite web|url=http://www.atlantajewish.com/content/2004/evanandjaron.html|title=American Jewish Life Magazine|website=Atlantajewish.com|accessdate=7 June 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212153007/http://www.atlantajewish.com/content/2004/evanandjaron.html|archive-date=12 February 2010|url-status=dead}}{{cite web|url=http://blogs.ajc.com/radio-tv-talk/2010/08/30/former-atlanta-rocker-jaron-of-evan-and-jaron-lassos-a-hit-in-country-music/ |title=Former Atlanta rocker Jaron of Evan and Jaron lassos a hit in country music | Radio & TV Talk |accessdate=July 18, 2012 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120514114718/http://blogs.ajc.com/radio-tv-talk/2010/08/30/former-atlanta-rocker-jaron-of-evan-and-jaron-lassos-a-hit-in-country-music/ |archivedate=May 14, 2012 }} Through his mother, he is related (by marriage) to actor [[Logan Lerman]].{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0503567/bio|title=Logan Lerman|website=IMDb.com|accessdate=7 June 2016}} In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Lowenstein recorded with his [[identical twin]] brother, Evan, in the [[pop music|pop]] duo [[Evan and Jaron]].{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/03/12/jaron-long-road-love-songs/|title=Jaron Prescribes Music as Antidote to Tough Times|date=March 12, 2010|work=The Boot|accessdate=March 12, 2010}} Evan and Jaron charted three [[single (music)|singles]], including "[[Crazy for This Girl]]," which reached number 15 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] charts in 2000.{{cite journal|date=1 February 2010|title=Who's New|journal=[[Country Weekly]]|volume=17|issue=5|pages=17|issn=1074-3235}} The duo split up in 2003 so that Evan could focus on raising his family. Jaron co-wrote and recorded his first solo single, "[[Pray for You (Jaron and the Long Road to Love song)|Pray for You]]", as Jaron and the Long Road to Love in late 2009.{{cite web|url=http://blog.cmt.com/2009-11-20/jaron-lowenstein-offers-a-prayer-for-your-ex/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091123193835/http://blog.cmt.com/2009-11-20/jaron-lowenstein-offers-a-prayer-for-your-ex/|url-status=dead|archive-date=November 23, 2009|title=Jaron Lowenstein Offers a Prayer for Your Ex|last=Bonaguro|first=Alison|date=November 20, 2009|work=[[Country Music Television|CMT]]|accessdate=November 24, 2009}} Starting in February 2010, [[Big Machine Records]] assumed promotion of the single and a forthcoming album, which was distributed through a partnership of Jaron's Jaronwood label and [[Universal Republic]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/71765/jaron-long-run-ink-deal-with-universal-republic?ref=search|title=Jaron & Long Run Ink Deal With Universal Republic|date=March 5, 2010|work=All Access|accessdate=March 25, 2010}} The song reached the top 40 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart and the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. Jaron told [[Technorati]] that the song "wasn't started or pushed by some major label or organization. I would love to take the credit for its success, but honestly this is something fans want and they are the ones calling radio to have them play it."{{cite web|url=http://technorati.com/entertainment/article/even-celebrities-arent-immune-to-valentines1/|title=Even Celebrities Aren't Immune To Valentine's Day Pressure|date=February 16, 2010|work=Technorati|accessdate=March 26, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100219010143/http://technorati.com/entertainment/article/even-celebrities-arent-immune-to-valentines1/|archive-date=February 19, 2010|url-status=dead}} Hank Friedmann directed a [[music video]] for the song, which has aired on [[CMT Pure Country]] (CMT Pure) and [[Great American Country]] (GAC).{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/videos/jaron-and-the-long-road-to-love/467605/pray-for-you.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100108012801/http://www.cmt.com/videos/jaron-and-the-long-road-to-love/467605/pray-for-you.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=January 8, 2010|title=Music video for "Pray for You"|work=CMT|accessdate=March 23, 2010}} A second video, which includes [[Jaime Pressly]], debuted in April 2010.{{cite web|url=http://blog.cmt.com/2010-04-12/jaron-gives-the-back-story-in-new-pray-for-you/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725192819/http://blog.cmt.com/2010-04-12/jaron-gives-the-back-story-in-new-pray-for-you/|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 25, 2011|title=Jaron Gives the Back Story in New "Pray for You"|last=Bonaguro|first=Alison|date=April 12, 2010|work=CMT|accessdate=April 12, 2010}} His debut album, ''Getting Dressed in the Dark'', was released on June 22, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2010/04/07/jaron-long-road-to-love-getting-dressed-in-the-dark-new-album/|title=Jaron Gets 'Dressed' for New Album|last=Hughes|first=Donna|date=April 7, 2010|work=The Boot|accessdate=April 12, 2010}} The album's second single is "That's Beautiful to Me", which debuted on the country chart at number 59 in September 2010. In early 2011, Lowenstein parted ways with [[Big Machine Records]] and [[Republic Nashville]]. Despite leaving the label, a third single from ''Getting Dressed in the Dark'', "It's a Good Thing", was released on April 18, 2011, with promotion from Nine North Records. However, the single failed to chart. On May 31, 2011, Lowenstein released "Beautiful Lies", which features [[Big Kenny]], one-half of the [[country music]] duo [[Big & Rich]]. The song is the lead-off single to Lowenstein's second album. The song also failed to chart. In 2011, eleven songs were released as a self-titled album by the band Cordovas. The band is made out of [[Joe Firstman]], Jaron Lowenstein, Jon Loyd, Johnny Gray, Parker Gins and Toby Weaver. The album was made available as a free download on the band's official website {{cite web|url=http://www.cordovasband.com|title=Cordovas|date=2011}} as well as other traditional paying outlets. The songs "Old Dog" and "All I Found" had videos released online. ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:22em;"| Album details ! colspan="2"| Peak chart
